subject: Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: It s a very nice first pass but a couple of points: - Received Pronunciation English pronounces north and awe the same thus north should be under the
messageBody:
It's a very nice first pass but a couple of points:

- Received Pronunciation English pronounces "north" and "awe" the same
thus "north" should be under the letter Awe #33 not #34
- RP pronounces "force" as "awe" and thus "force" needs to be under
the letter Awe #33 not #34
- RP pronounces "cure" and "foot" with the same vowel. So "cure" is
#39 Foot+Roe in that accent.
- in RP, "near" and "it" use the same vowel thus "near" uses #26 It +
Roe not #27
- "happy" should never be end with #27 or anything but #26: This is
one of the few mandatory non-phonetic rules. How Read pronounces
"happy" shouldn't be inferred from this and is irrelevant anyway since
spelling is constant in this case.

It seems there can indeed be much doubt about (or did you not say
"ignorance of" ;-) Read's pronunciation of his letters.
But jibes aside, ( I couldn't help myself ;-) it is a very useful
exercise. If you would be so kind as to make such a mapping for your
personal accent I could add it to the grand list.


--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
> Here's a rough mapping from the 27 Wells lexical sets
> (reminder: you can see sample words at
> http://www.ic.arizona.edu/~anth383/lexicalsets.html )
> to QS vowel letters and combinations:
>
> KIT #26 It
> DRESS #28 Et
> TRAP #30 At
> LOT #34 Ox; may be merged with #32 Ah or #33 Awe or both
> STRUT #36 Utter
> FOOT #39 Foot; may be merged with #36 Utter or #40 Ooze
> BATH Either #30 At or #32 Ah, depending on dialect
> CLOTH Either #34 Ox or #33 Awe, depending on dialect [*]
> NURSE #36 Utter followed by #25 Roe
> FLEECE #27 Eat
> FACE #29 Eight
> PALM #32 Ah; may be merged with #33 Awe or #34 Ox or both
> THOUGHT #33 Awe; may be merged with #32 Ah or #34 Ox or both
> GOAT #38 Owe
> GOOSE #40 Ooze; may be merged with #39 Foot
> PRICE #31 I; may be merged with #32 Ah
> CHOICE #35 Oy
> MOUTH #37 Out
> NEAR #27 Eat followed by #25 Roe
> SQUARE #29 Eight or #28 Et, depending on dialect, followed by
#25 Roe
> START #32 Ah [*] followed by #25 Roe
> NORTH #34 On [*] or #38 Owe, depending on dialect, followed by
#25 Roe
> FORCE #38 Owe or #34 On [*], depending on dialect, followed by
#25 Roe
> CURE #40 Ooze or #33 Awe [*], depending on dialect, followed
by #25 Roe
> HAPPY Read says #26 It, although #27 Eat is used by most
people now
> LETTER #36 Utter followed by #25 Roe
> COMMA #36 Utter
>
> [*] May involve further mergers.
>
> It's only rough because there are other mergers in various dialects
> that aren't represented here: psalm/sum, bud/bird, pin/pen, mit/meet,
> met/mat, meet/mate, bit/bet, cot/coat, rod/ride, pride/proud, line/loin,
> merry/Mary/merry, hurry/furry, furry/ferry, cheer/chair, fur/fair,
> stir/steer, tower/tire, tower/tar, tire/tar, cure/fir, card/cord. Yes,
> somewhere there is a group of people who pronounce each pair of words
> identically (and not just those words, many other pairs too).
>
> --
> John Cowan <cowan@...> http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
> Today an interactive brochure website, tomorrow a global content
> management system that leverages collective synergy to drive "outside of
> the box" thinking and formulate key objectives into a win-win game plan
> with a quality-driven approach that focuses on empowering key players
> to drive-up their core competencies and increase expectations with an
> all-around initiative to drive up the bottom-line. --Alex Papadimoulis
>
